channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: As Federal Guidelines Expire, States Struggle to Reopen
item.description: More than 30 million people have filed for unemployment in the last six weeks. Beaches could close in California. Dr. Fauci says he is optimistic that a vaccine could be available as early as January.

item.title: Should the Virus Mean Straight A’s for Everyone?
item.description: Schools nationwide are debating whether to issue grades to high school students during the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein
item.media:credit: Kevin Hagen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City said high school students would receive letter grades but also have the option of a pass/fail system.

item.title: Bridge Was Their Passion. Then People Started to Die.
item.description: A bridge club was a social draw for scores of older Coloradans. Now, with four members dead from the virus, its future is unclear.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy

item.title: ‘Will You Help Save My Brother?’: The Scramble to Find Covid-19 Plasma Donors
item.description: A doctor stricken with Covid-19 was running out of options. His family mounted a search for a donor whose plasma might help.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch and Amy Harmon
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Basil Binns II, who had recovered from the coronavirus, was asked to donate plasma to help a stranger battling the infection.

item.title: Macy’s Plans to Reopen All of Its 775 Stores in 6 to 8 Weeks
item.description: The chain’s plans also brought into sharper focus what the pandemic-era shopping experience may look like.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari
item.media:description: Macy’s reopening plans are the latest sign of how eager the nation’s largest retailers are to return to business.

item.title: High School Seniors Are Making Yearbooks on Instagram
item.description: The class of 2020 has given up prom, graduation and other rites, but they’re sharing memories and celebrating each other’s achievements online.
item.dc:creator: Taylor Lorenz

item.title: He Indicted Netanyahu, but Sees No Reason to Bar Him From Office
item.description: Israel's Supreme Court is to hear arguments on petitions to disqualify the prime minister, who faces trial on corruption charges, and against a coalition deal.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on election night in March.

item.title: Four Amish Children Dead and One Is Missing After Buggy Overturns
item.description: A deputy coroner in northeastern Kentucky said their mother was able to reach the banks of a waterway and summon help on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: Rescue teams arriving at the scene of a buggy accident in northeastern Kentucky on Wednesday in which four Amish children died. A fifth child remained missing on Thursday.

item.title: National Security Surveillance on U.S. Soil Fell Amid Scrutiny of Russia Inquiry
item.description: But overseas targets of the government’s warrantless surveillance program continued to soar in 2019, a new report disclosed.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:description: The F.B.I.’s national security surveillance wiretap program has recently come under scrutiny.

item.title: Restaurant Burglaries on the Rise as Thieves Target the Liquor
item.description: Emboldened by the vacant streets and empty dining rooms, thieves in some cities are targeting restaurants.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Sasha Rudensky for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jesus Puerto’s restaurant, Soul De Cuba in New Haven, Conn., was broken into by a burglar who stayed for several days. Mr. Puerto says he is now out thousands of dollars.

item.title: Texas Man Is Accused of Opening Fire at the Cuban Embassy in Washington
item.description: There were no reports of injuries, the authorities said. The man was charged with assault with intent to kill.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: The police and Secret Service officers were called to the scene at about 2:15 a.m., after receiving reports of gunfire by the Cuban Embassy in Washington.

item.title: Old Drugs May Find a New Purpose: Fighting the Coronavirus
item.description: A “drug repurposing” strategy uncovers dozens of compounds that have the unexpected potential to combat the virus.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: A scanning electron micrograph of a dying cell infected with coronavirus particles, in orange.

item.title: Stymied in Seeking Benefits, Millions of Unemployed Go Uncounted
item.description: As state agencies grapple with new guidelines and sheer volume, many workers are frustrated in filing claims and omitted from jobless tallies.
item.dc:creator: Nelson D. Schwartz, Tiffany Hsu and Patricia Cohen
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: Joy Harjo Is Named U.S. Poet Laureate for a Second Term
item.description: The first Native American to hold the position, Harjo will be developing an interactive map of contemporary Native poets.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León
item.media:description: Joy Harjo, whose books include “An American Sunrise” and “Crazy Brave,” in 2019.

item.title: On Politics: Pressure Grows on Biden
item.description: Calls to respond to an allegation, and promising coronavirus news: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Coronavirus, Remdesivir, Unemployment: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Biden Reveals Allies Who Will Help Pick a Running Mate
item.description: Announcing the leaders of his vice-presidential selection committee, Joe Biden moved his search for a running mate into a new phase, with a vetting process that might last until July.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has promised to select a female running mate, and has mentioned numerous potential contenders.

item.title: Trump’s Disinfectant Talk Trips Up Sites’ Vows Against Misinformation
item.description: Facebook, Twitter and YouTube have declined to remove the president’s statements about unproven coronavirus treatments.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Davey Alba
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump suggested last Thursday that an “injection inside” the body with a disinfectant could help fight the coronavirus. His comments took off on social media.

item.title: Justin Amash, Third-Party Spoiler? Michigan Experts Are Skeptical
item.description: Democrats worry that if the congressman runs for president, he could siphon votes in a state Donald Trump narrowly won four years ago. But strategists say this election is much different.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel and Jonathan Martin
item.media:description: Representative Justin Amash of Michigan, a frequent critic of President Trump, left the Republican Party last year to become an independent.

item.title: As Georgia Reopens, Virus Study Shows Black Residents May Bear Brunt
item.description: A C.D.C. report released Wednesday suggests that the African-American community in the state is especially vulnerable to infection.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia has moved to restart the state’s economy.

item.title: PG&E’s Settlement With Wildfire Victims Faces Crucial Vote
item.description: Some victims think the $13.5 billion deal is flawed and are worried that a lawyer who negotiated it has a conflict of interest.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pacific Gas & Electric’s equipment has caused more devastating fires than any other California utility as measured by liability claims against the company.

item.title: States Made It Harder to Get Jobless Benefits. Now That’s Hard to Undo.
item.description: Systems that were devised to treat each case as potentially fraudulent are now rushing to deal with millions of newly unemployed people.
item.dc:creator: Emily Badger and Alicia Parlapiano
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: Chinese Coffee Chain’s Scandal Renews U.S. Calls for Oversight
item.description: The implosion of a Chinese competitor to Starbucks has bolstered the cause of American politicians aiming to stop opaque Chinese companies from raising money in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Lucia Buricelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luckin Coffee went public on the Nasdaq exchange in New York last May.

item.title: World Coronavirus Tracker: Live Coverage
item.description: But there was a positive milestone: no new cases in South Korea and Hong Kong.
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A slum in Mumbai. South Asia is expected to have its worst economic performance in 40 years because of the pandemic.

item.title: Flynn Lawyers Seize on Newly Released F.B.I. Documents
item.description: The documents show details of a debate among F.B.I. officials before interviewing Michael T. Flynn in 2017, days after he lied to the vice president about his talks with a top Russian diplomat.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s first national security adviser, in 2018.

item.title: Unemployment Claims Top 30 Million in U.S.: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange on Thursday.

item.title: Emissions Declines Will Set Records This Year. But It’s Not Good News.
item.description: An “unprecedented” fall in fossil fuel use, driven by the Covid-19 crisis, is likely to lead to a nearly 8 percent drop, according to new research.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:description: A coal-burning power plant in Megalopolis, Greece, in March.

item.title: 21-Year-Old Man Charged in Fatal Shooting of Indianapolis Postal Worker
item.description: Angela Summers, 45, was delivering mail along her route when she was shot by an upset customer on Monday, court documents show.
item.dc:creator: Mariel Padilla and Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: Grace Hollars/The Indianapolis Star, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A flag flies at half-staff at the Linwood Post Office in Indianapolis in honor of Angela Summers, a postal worker who was killed on Monday.

item.title: F.A.A. Investigates Harrison Ford and His Plane Again
item.description: The episode was being investigated by the Federal Aviation Administration, which ordered the actor to complete awareness training in 2017.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Harrison Ford, seen here in February, misheard a radio instruction from an air traffic controller after landing his plane last week, his publicist said.

item.title: Prisoner With Coronavirus Dies After Giving Birth While on Ventilator
item.description: Andrea Circle Bear, the first female federal prisoner to die after getting the coronavirus, had just started serving a two-year drug sentence for selling methamphetamine.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Vanessa Swales
item.media:description: Federal Medical Center Carswell in Fort Worth, Texas

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The drug of hope. Can remdesivir help?
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: The Trump Administration’s Legal Moves to Prevent a Meat Shortage, Explained
item.description: Contrary to misunderstandings, the actions fall short of ordering meatpacking facilities to reopen despite Covid-19 outbreaks among workers.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: “This is more symbolism than substance,” Stephen I. Vladeck, a professor of national security law, said of the order.

item.title: Trump Seeks Push to Speed Coronavirus Vaccine, Despite Safety Concerns
item.description: The president wants a coronavirus vaccine widely available by the end of the year, even though his public health experts say it will take at least a year to 18 months.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority
item.media:description: President Trump’s order came as he grew increasingly frustrated with a warning by Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, left, that a vaccine would take at least a year to produce.

item.title: Trump and Kushner on the Coronavirus: Wishful Thinking and Revisionist History
item.description: “We did all the right moves,” the president said Wednesday. “The federal government rose to the challenge, and this is a great success story,” said his son-in-law.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with Gov. John Bel Edwards of Louisiana on Wednesday in the Oval Office.

item.title: Powerful Meat Industry Holds More Sway After Trump’s Order
item.description: The executive action signals that decisions around whether to close or reopen plants should be driven by the federal government, not local authorities.
item.dc:creator: Michael Corkery, David Yaffe-Bellany and Ana Swanson
item.category: United Food and Commercial Workers Union
item.media:credit: Jessica Pettway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meat companies have warned that the country’s food supply is in peril.

item.title: Q.&.A. With Justin Amash
item.description: “What we need in Washington is a little more humility and trust of the people,” said Mr. Amash, a Michigan congressman and former Republican. He told us why he was seeking the Libertarian Party’s presidential nomination.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: Representative Justin Amash of Michigan.

item.title: Roger Stone Was in Contact With Julian Assange in 2017, Documents Show
item.description: Mr. Stone, a longtime friend of President Trump, had denied such a relationship, but newly revealed court documents unveiled private exchanges.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roger J. Stone Jr. was sentenced to 40 months in prison after being convicted of obstructing a congressional inquiry, lying to federal authorities and witness tampering in a bid to protect President Trump.

item.title: Polls Had Trump Stewing, and Lashing Out at His Own Campaign
item.description: The president erupted recently at his campaign manager, Brad Parscale, after seeing polling data that showed Mr. Trump trailing Joe Biden in several states.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Annie Karni
item.media:description: President Trump has slipped behind his Democratic opponent, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., in some recent polls of battleground states.

item.title: People Are Talking About ‘Travel Bubbles.’ But Could They Work?
item.description: Australia and New Zealand floated the idea of a regional alliance that would let those inside travel but keep the coronavirus out. But in other parts of the world, establishing one would be tricky.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa
item.media:credit: From left: Lauryn Ishak for The New York Times; Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: Australia’s prime minister has suggested that a “travel bubble” could include sites in his country, and New Zealand, allowing travelers to visit Australia’s Northern Territory (left) and New Zealand’s Punakaiki Pancake Rocks and Blowholes.

item.title: Coronavirus Has Trump Health Secretary in Trouble
item.description: Alex M. Azar II has long been seen as a difficult personality in President Trump’s cabinet, but the pandemic has heightened personal clashes, putting him on thin ice.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland, Maggie Haberman and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Alex M. Azar II, the health secretary, is being increasingly sidelined by President Trump and his advisers, who blame him for early failures on testing for the coronavirus.

item.title: Alaska School District Votes Out ‘Catch-22,’ ‘Gatsby’ and Other Classics
item.description: School board members in Palmer, Alaska, raised concerns about language and sexual references in five books deemed too controversial.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings (Book)
item.media:credit: Scribner, via Associated Press; Simon & Schuster; Ballantine Books
item.media:description: “The Great Gatsby,” “Catch-22” and “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings” are three of the five books the Matanuska-Susitna Borough School District voted to remove from a student reading list.

item.title: Elite Prep Schools, Set Back by Virus, Face a Quandary on Federal Aid
item.description: The loans were meant as a payroll lifeline for small businesses. Many of the schools had endowments in the tens of millions. Their administrators grappled with a question: to take or not to take?
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess and David McCabe
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: St. Andrew’s Episcopal School in Potomac, Md., has decided to keep its federal stimulus loan.

item.title: Tara Reade Assault Allegation: Democrats' Frustration Mounts as Biden Remains Silent
item.description: Activists and women’s rights advocates have urged Mr. Biden to address a former aide’s allegation that he sexually assaulted her in 1993. His lack of response has angered them.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Sydney Ember
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at a news conference in Wilmington, Del., last month. He has yet to discuss the sexual assault allegation against him or be asked about it in an interview.

item.title: New Coronavirus Test Offers Advantages: Just Spit and Wait
item.description: Saliva tests like the one developed by Rutgers are less painful for patients and less risky to medical workers.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
item.media:description: Health workers administered a new saliva-based test for coronavirus in Edison, N.J., on April 15.
